modules¶

tstoolkit.anomaly_detection module¶

class tstoolkit.anomaly_detection.TimeSeriesAnomalyDetector¶

Bases: object

TimeSeriesAnomalyDetector Class.

fit(data: DataFrame) → None¶

Fit an anomaly detection model to the time series data.

Parameters:

data (pd.DataFrame) – Timeseries DataFrame.

plot_anomalies() → None¶

Plot the time series data with detected anomalies highlighted.

predict(algorithm: str = 'isolation_forest') → list¶

Predict anomalies in the time series data.

Parameters:

algorithm (str, optional) – The algorithm to use for anomaly detection. Options available are isolation_forest, local_outlier_factor and one_class_svm, defaults to “isolation_forest”

Raises:

ValueError – Unsupported algorithm

Returns:

List of anomaly scores

Return type:

list

tstoolkit.data_preprocess module¶

class tstoolkit.data_preprocess.DataManager(data_path: Path, artifacts_path: Path = Path('artifacts'))¶

Bases: object

Class to manage data for the toolkit.

Parameters:

  • data_path (Path) – The path to the data file.

  • artifacts_path (Path, optional) – The path where to store the artifacts, defaults to Path(“artifacts”)

get_forecasting_data(data: DataFrame, steps_past: int = 200, steps_future: int = 24) → tuple[ndarray, ndarray]¶

Gets the forecasting data.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Data

  • steps_past (int, optional) – The number of steps to look back , defaults to 200

  • steps_future (int, optional) – The number of steps to look forward , defaults to 24

Returns:

The inputs x of shape (batch_size, n_vars, seq_len) and outputs `y`of shape (batch_size, n_vars, horizon).

Return type:

tuple[np.ndarray, np.ndarray]

interpolate_nulls(data: DataFrame, interpolation_method: str = 'linear', polynomial_order: int = 5) → DataFrame¶

Fill nulls in the data using interpolation.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Data with nulls

  • interpolation_method (str, optional) – Interpolation Method. All possible Methods are pandas.DataFrame.interpolate() , defaults to “linear”

  • polynomial_order (int, optional) – Order for polynomial interpolation, defaults to 5

Returns:

Data with gaps filled

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

load_data() → DataFrame¶

Get HD5 Format File.

Returns:

data

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

preprocess_data(data: DataFrame, index: str = 'DateTime', columns: str = 'PropertyID', values: str = 'Value') → DataFrame¶

Reshape and pivot the data.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Data to be preprocessed

  • index (str, optional) – The index to use, defaults to “DateTime”

  • columns (str, optional) – Column to use as Sensor ID, defaults to “PropertyID”

  • values (str, optional) – Column to use as sensor value, defaults to “Value”

Returns:

Preprocessed data

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

split_data(data: DataFrame, steps_past: int = 200, steps_future: int = 24, validation_size: float = 0.1, test_size: float = 0.2, show_plot: bool = True) → tuple¶

Creates the train/validation/test splits.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Data

  • steps_past (int, optional) – The number of steps to look back as history, defaults to 200

  • steps_future (int, optional) – The number of steps to look forward, defaults to 24

  • validation_size (float, optional) – The size of the validation set, defaults to 0.1

  • test_size (float, optional) – The size of the test set, defaults to 0.2

  • show_plot (bool, optional) – Whether to show the split plot, defaults to True

Returns:

The train/validation/test splits indexes.

Return type:

tuple

standardize_data(data: DataFrame, splits: tuple, columns: list[str], verbose: bool = False, artifact_name: str = 'standardize_pipe') → DataFrame¶

Standardize the data using a standardization pipeline.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Data to be standardized

  • splits (tuple) – The train/validation/test splits.

  • columns (list[str]) – The columns to standardize

  • verbose (bool, optional) – Whether to show the pipeline logs, defaults to False

  • artifact_name (str, optional) – The name of the artifact to be saved , defaults to “standardize_pipe”

Returns:

Standardized Data

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

Bases: object

Class for Filling Gaps in Time Series data.

fit(first_ts: Series, second_ts: Series) → None¶

Fitting Gap Filling Method.

Parameters:

  • first_ts (pd.Series) – Part of Time series before the gap.

  • second_ts (pd.Series) – Part of time series after the gap.

merge_ts() → Series¶

Returning a merged time series of all three parts.

Returns:

Merged Time series

Return type:

pd.Series

plot_ts() → None¶

Plot all three parts of time series combined.

predict() → Series¶

Getting the filled time series.

Returns:

Filled Time Series

Bases: Enum

An enum that represents the split type.

TEST = 'test'¶
TRAIN = 'train'¶
VALID = 'valid'¶
class tstoolkit.models.TsaiLearnerManager(arch: str, arch_config: dict, loss_func: Callable, metrics: list[Callable], x: ndarray, y: ndarray, splits: tuple, artifacts_path: Path, batch_size: int, pipelines: Iterable[Pipeline] = ((),), callbacks: Iterable[Callback] = ((),), **kwargs)¶

Bases: LearnerManager

A class that manages the Tsai learners.

Parameters:

  • arch (str) – The architecture to use.

  • arch_config (dict) – The architecture configuration.

  • loss_func (Callable) – The loss function for training.

  • metrics (list[Callable]) – Evaluation metrics.

  • x (np.ndarray) – The inputs x.

  • y (np.ndarray) – The inputs y.

  • splits (tuple) – The train/val/test splits.

  • artifacts_path (Path) – The path where to store the artifacts (checkpoints).

  • batch_size (int) – The batch size.

  • pipelines (Iterable[Pipeline], optional) – The data-preprocessing pipelines.

  • callbacks (Iterable[Callback], optional) – The callbacks used during training.

evaluate(x: ndarray, y_true: ndarray, split_type: SplitType = SplitType.VALID) → DataFrame¶

Evaluates the validation set.

Parameters:

  • x (np.ndarray) – The inputs of shape (batch_size, n_vars, seq_len)

  • y_true (np.ndarray) – The targets of shape (batch_size, n_vars, horizon)

  • split_type (SplitType, optional) – The split type., defaults to SplitType.VALID

Returns:

Evaluation Metrics Value

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

export_model(artifact_name: str) → None¶

Exports the model.

Parameters:

artifact_name (str) – Name of the artifact to be saved.

find_max_lr() → float¶

Find the maximum learning rate.

Returns:

Max Learning Rate

Return type:

float

fit(epochs: int, lr_max: float | None = None) → None¶

Fits the model.

Parameters:

  • epochs (int) – Number of Epochs

  • lr_max (float | None, optional) – Learning Rate, defaults to None

get_forecast_plot(x: ndarray, y_true: ndarray, y_pred: ndarray, sel_vars: bool = True, idx: int = 0) → None¶

Gets the forecast plot.

Parameters:

  • x (np.ndarray) – The inputs of shape (batch_size, n_vars, seq_len)

  • y_true (np.ndarray) – The targets of shape (batch_size, n_vars, horizon)

  • y_pred (np.ndarray) – The predictions of shape (batch_size, n_vars, horizon)

  • sel_vars (bool, optional) – Whether to plot the variable separately., defaults to True

  • idx (int, optional) – The index of the sample in the batch to plot., defaults to 0

get_summary() → str¶

Returns the summary of the learner.

Returns:

Summary

Return type:

str

Loads the model.

Parameters:

artifact_name (str) – Name of the artifact to be loaded.

Parameters:

x (np.ndarray) – The inputs of shape (batch_size, n_vars, seq_len)

Returns:

The predictions of shape (batch_size, n_vars, horizon)

class tstoolkit.similarity.TimeSeriesSimilarityChecker¶

Bases: object

A class for performing similarity checks on time series data.

Calculate cosine similarity between two columns.

Parameters:

  • col1 (str) – Name of the first column.

  • col2 (str) – Name of the second column.

Returns:

Cosine similarity.

Return type:

float

dynamic_time_warping(col1: str, col2: str) → float¶

Calculate Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) distance between two columns.

Parameters:

  • col1 (str) – Name of the first column.

  • col2 (str) – Name of the second column.

Returns:

DTW distance.

Return type:

float

fit(data: DataFrame) → None¶

Fit Similarity Checker.

Parameters:

data (pd.DataFrame) – DataFrame containing time series data with DateTime index.

pearson_correlation(col1: str, col2: str) → float¶

Calculate Pearson correlation coefficient between two columns.

Parameters:

  • col1 (str) – Name of the first column.

  • col2 (str) – Name of the second column.

Returns:

Pearson correlation coefficient.

float
